title: Chris Arnade, author of Dignity, on Economic Displacement, Addiction and Reciprocal Narrowing
description:
Jordan Peterson, Culture and Anomaly
https://youtu.be/Bj6HgQBNiZE

John Vervaeke, Awakening from the Meaning Crisis.    https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLND1JCRq8Vuh3f0P5qjrSdb5eC1ZfZwWJ

Jordan Peterson
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL22J3VaeABQD_IZs7y60I3lUrrFTzkpat
Growing up Catholic in a family of 7 children, got a PHD in Physics followed by a switch to Wall Street Trading. 

Dignity, page 14   You realized you “needed to stop trying to save them, but just to listen and understand.”

Did you stop trying to save them because you realized that was counter-productive? 

Your writing is brutally straight forward. Did you have to work at developing that style? These stories are desperately sad and painful, yet without sentimentality. Just honesty in your plain description of their circumstances.

You introduce us to the very real people that have been affected by economic choices that were made in the face of rising global competition.

p. 50
“In the name of economic growth, more efficiency and higher profits, we opened our borders to a flood of cheaper products coming in and a flood of factories and jobs moving away… to lower labor costs, no matter what.”

What, in your estimation, would have been a more productive stance to have taken in the face of the existing growth of global competition?

How that addiction has affected their lives. Did you develop your interest and study of addiction after you started this project, or before?

John Vervaeke, The Meaning Crisis, reciprocal narrowing. Relationship between agent and arena, or individual and world they inhabit. Your world becomes a little smaller - I can’t continue my job because the drugs affect my thinking. My lack of a job narrows my world - no entertainment, no travel, no options. That reinforces my dependence on the drugs. My world gets narrower. I can’t do that thing because I need to get my next hit. And on down it goes. 

Your description of this world shows clearly the impact of addiction and lack of education. 

p. 284
EDUCATION
“We have said that education is the way out of pain and the way to success, implying that those who don’t make it out are dumb, lazy, or stupid.” That’s one way to see the implications, but not a necessary one. If we say that education is not the way out of pain and the way to success, what exactly have we achieved? We will always bump up against reality.

Addiction starts way early for many of these people, even in junior high. That obviously affects their ability to focus on school to get a high school education. The 3 factors that have the most impact on a future without poverty are a high school education, marriage and waiting until marriage to have children. Many of those you met had children in their teens. It sounds like any intervention needs to come much much sooner.

African American pastor was asking for tutors for kids grade 3 through 5 to help them get their reading up to grade level as that would greatly increase their opportunities for flourishing as adults.

Students who were not proficient in reading by the end of third grade were four times more likely to drop out of high school than proficient readers. In fact, 88 percent of students who failed to earn a high school diploma were struggling readers in third grade.
Third grade has been identified as important to reading literacy because it is the final year children are learning to read, after which students are “reading to learn.” If not proficient readers when they begin fourth grade, as much as half of the curriculum they are taught will be incomprehensible.

3 things.
Finish High School
Don’t have a child before twenty
Get married, then have a child.

What if we had a story for children that you can have a meaningful life filled with promise, and that the first step on that journey is learning to read? What about using phonics so that all children would have the opportunity to read at or above grade level? Rudolf Flesch - Why Johnny Can’t Read

“True compassion is doing what is right for someone. A parent doesn’t do their kid any good letting them blame the world for their problems.”

An ideology leaves no room for uniqueness. The agenda requires that all see through the same lens, all come to the same conclusion. 

Also, addiction leaves no room for uniqueness. Addiction reduces everyone down to the same common denominator. Desperate need and a willingness to do anything to meet that need.

Reciprocal broadening - become a little more open, more flexible in thinking, then you get more curious and learn more. That broadens your horizons and shows you more possibilities. Your arm gets higher. You learn more, grow more.

At the mention of Jordan Peterson, Chris Arnade mentioned right wing and alt-right movements. JP has no connection with such movements and no affinity.

AGENCY.  When you tell someone, the system is against you, what does that accomplish?
If the system is the problem, I have no agency and also have no responsibility.
